importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous longest government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and ended on January 25, 2019.
The end date of the 35-day government shutdown that was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The date of the latest update to the article, indicating ongoing government shutdown as of that time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the longest government shutdown in history, lasting 35 days and costing the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The current ongoing government shutdown, with no passage of the 12 required appropriations bills, resulting in a full shutdown.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown — from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019 — was the longest in nearly 50 years, lasting 35 days.
That shutdown cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
The current government shutdown is a full shutdown, as no 12 appropriations bills have been passed by Congress.
The 2018 shutdown was partial, with some agencies continuing operations and about 300,000 employees furloughed.
In the current shutdown, approximately 800,000 people were affected across shuttered federal agencies, with both furloughed and exempted employees receiving backpay upon reopening.
Partisan gridlock in Congress, particularly with a narrow House majority and lack of 60 Senate votes to end a filibuster, has prolonged the shutdown.
Government shutdowns have become less frequent since 1990, but political polarization continues to delay resolution of spending disputes.
The first federal government shutdown occurred in 1976, according to CNN research.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central subject of the article — the shutdown of federal operations due to lack of funding.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan agency that provides economic and budgetary analysis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided the estimate that the 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. $3 billion in lost GDP.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A date marking the start of a major government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The beginning of the longest government shutdown in nearly 50 years.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A date marking the end of a major government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The conclusion of the 35-day shutdown that set a record for duration.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He oversees the current Congress, which is facing narrow majorities and political deadlock that contributed to the ongoing shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule allowing extended debate to block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Republican Party lacks 60 votes to overcome a filibuster, making legislative compromise difficult and contributing to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal funding legislation required to sustain all government operations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: No passage of these bills has occurred, leading to a full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing public updates and analysis on the current and past government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Number of people employed in shuttered federal agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights the scale of human impact during the 2018 shutdown, with about 300,000 furloughed.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Number of employees not paid and asked not to report to work
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates the economic and personal cost of government shutdowns on public workers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reports that the U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass the required 12 appropriations bills. This marks a continuation of political deadlock, echoing the 2018 shutdown — the longest in nearly 50 years, which lasted 35 days from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, and cost the nation an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. The 2018 shutdown was partial, with some agencies operating and about 300,000 employees furloughed, while the current shutdown is full, affecting all federal operations. The article attributes the ongoing impasse to deep political polarization, a narrow Republican House majority, and the inability to overcome Senate filibusters. It also notes that government shutdowns have declined in frequency since 1990, but partisan gridlock continues to delay funding resolutions.
title: The US government remains shut down: Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
